question.text: The expression 'gynoecium is polycarpellary apocarpous' implies that the

options.text: Gynoecium comprises only one pistil which is fused with the stamen
Gynoecium comprises more than one carpel, all of which are free
Gynoecium comprises only one carpel which is free
Gynoecium comprises more than one carpel which are fused

solution.text: Gynoecium having a single carpel is called monocarpellary (two carpels: bicarpellary, three: tricarpellary, many: polycarpellary). Carpels may be free, then the gynoecium is called apocarpous (e.g., polycarpellary apocarpous in rose, lotus and Ranunculus) and when they are fused, the gynoecium is known to be syncarpous.
